Release 82 of the Official Code of Kentucky Annotated released 2022.05 Transformed and posted by Public.Resource.Org using cic-beautify-state-codes.py version v1.12 on 2022-07-13. This document is not subject to copyright and is in the public domain.

Title 15 Cities and Towns

  • Chapter 1 General Provisions
  • Chapter 2 Incorporated Towns
  • Chapter 3 First Class Cities
  • Chapter 4 Alternative Forms of Government
  • Chapter 5 Fire and Police Departments

  • Chapter 9 Urban Renewal
  • Chapter 10 Housing Projects
  • Chapter 11 Municipal Election Provisions

Revision of title. —

Laws 1980, ch. 38, § 1, revised this title, amending and renumbering §§ 15-1-101 to 15-11-18 as 15-1-101 to 15-10-117. No detailed explanation of the changes made by the 1980 Act have been attempted, but, where appropriate, historical citations to former provisions have been added to corresponding sections in this title, and annotations from cases decided under former provisions have been placed under comparable sections in this title where it was felt they would be helpful. For tables of revised and renumbered sections, see Volume 11 of the Wyoming Statutes Annotated.

Laws 1980, ch. 38, § 2, reads: “Any other act adopted by the Wyoming legislature during the same session in which this act is adopted shall be given precedence and shall prevail over the amendments in this act to the extent that such acts are in conflict.” Section 3, ch. 38, Laws 1980, makes the act effective on January 1, 1981.

  • Article 11. Quasi-Municipal Districts

Cross references. —

For provision prohibiting the legislature from delegating power to perform municipal functions, see art. 3, § 37, Wyo. Const.

For provision that no person except a qualified elector shall be elected or appointed to any civil or military office in the state, see art. 6, § 15, Wyo. Const.

As to when officer to hold over, and as to suspension of officers of state and municipality, see art. 6, § 16, Wyo. Const.

As to method of selecting officers whose election is not provided for in the constitution, see art. 6, § 18, Wyo. Const.

For provision that neither the state, nor any county, township, school district or municipality shall loan or give its credit or make donations to or in aid of any railroad or telegraph line, see art. 10, § 15, Wyo. Const.

For constitutional provisions relative to municipal corporations generally, see art. 13, §§ 1 to 5, Wyo. Const.

As to consolidation of offices in state, county and municipalities, see art. 14, § 6, Wyo. Const.

For provisions limiting city tax levy, see art. 15, § 6, Wyo. Const.

For provision that the power of taxation shall never be surrendered or suspended by any grant or contract to which the state or any county or any other municipal corporation shall be a party, see art. 15, § 14, Wyo. Const.

As to creation of municipal debt in excess of taxes for current year, see art. 16, § 4, Wyo. Const.

As to limitation on municipal debt, see art. 16, § 5, Wyo. Const.

For provision prohibiting loans or credit donations by state or any political subdivision thereof and requiring two-thirds vote of people for works of internal improvement, see art. 16, § 6, Wyo. Const.

As to eminent domain generally, see §§ 1-26-501 through 1-26-817 and Rule 71.1, W.R.C.P.

As to actions by or against the state, state agencies and political subdivisions generally, see §§ 1-35-101 to 1-35-108.

As to exemption of state, counties and municipalities, and their departments and agencies, from requirements of depositing security for damages, etc., in any civil, criminal or special proceeding generally, see § 1-35-108.

As to municipal courts generally, see ch. 6 of title 5.

As to unlawful conduct within governmental facilities, see §§ 6-6-301 through 6-6-307.

For the Wyoming Community Development Authority Act, see §§ 9-7-101 through 9-7-125.

For provision empowering local governmental units to cooperate with each other and with United States, see § 16-1-101.

For the Wyoming Joint Powers Act, see §§ 16-1-102 through 16-1-110.

For provisions relating to meetings of governmental agencies, see §§ 16-4-401 through 16-4-408.

As to county government generally, see title 18.

As to municipal elections generally, see §§ 22-23-101 to 22-23-1007.

For provisions relating to county, municipal and district health departments, see §§ 35-1-301 to 35-1-309.

As to community human services, see §§ 35-1-611 to 35-1-628.

As to municipal cemetery generally, see §§ 35-8-201 to 35-8-212.

Law reviews. —

For note on home rule as a solution for municipal problems, see 16 Wyo. L.J. 47 (1961).

For article, “Governmental Immunity from Damage Actions in Wyoming,” see VII Land & Water L. Rev. 229 (1972).

Acquisition by adverse possession or use of public property held by municipal corporation or other governmental unit otherwise than for streets, alleys, parks or commons, 55 ALR2d 554.

Municipal property as subject to mechanic's lien, 51 ALR3d 657.

  • § 15-1-108.  Powers and duties of mayor; appointment of mayor pro tem.
  • § 15-1-109.  When clerk may administer oaths.
  • § 15-1-110.  Minutes of meetings and titles of ordinances passed to be published; exception; contents; publication of salary information of specified officials and employees.

  • § 15-1-131.  Communications companies franchise agreements authorized; limitations; procedure; exceptions.

§ 15-1-101. Definitions.

  1. As used in W.S. 15-1-101 through 15-11-302:
    1. “Any city or town” means any incorporated municipality;
    2. “Councilman or councilmen” means the individuals elected to comprise the governing body of any city or town;
    3. “Emergency ordinance” means an ordinance operating for the immediate preservation of the public peace, health, safety or welfare, in which the emergency is defined;
    4. “First class city” means any incorporated municipality having a population of four thousand (4,000) or more which has been declared a first class city or which has taken the necessary steps to be and has been proclaimed a first class city;
    5. “Franchise” means the grant of authority to any person or firm by the governing body of any city or town to carry on the operation of a public utility;
    6. “Governing body” means the council or commission constituting the elected legislative body of any city or town including the mayor who is the presiding officer;
    7. “Local improvement” means any improvement made within any city or town, the cost of which may be assessed against the property specially benefited thereby;
    8. “Mayor” means the person elected, either by popular vote or by vote of the governing body, to exercise the powers of the office and to be presiding officer of the governing body;
    9. “Ordinance” means a legislative enactment of general effect validly adopted by the governing body of any city or town;
    10. “Person” means any individual, firm, partnership, corporation or other business entity, or the executor, administrator, trustee, receiver, assignee or personal representative thereof;
    11. “Public improvement” means an improvement made within any city or town for which general bonded obligation may be incurred;
    12. “Qualified elector” means any person possessing the requisite qualifications to vote in any election conducted within a city or town for the selection of mayors or councilmen;
    13. “Qualified member” means any member of a governing body who was elected or appointed thereto in accordance with all applicable provisions of law;
    14. “Town” means any incorporated municipality, not a first class city;
    15. “This act”, unless otherwise specified, means W.S. 15-1-101 through 15-11-302.

History. Laws 1965, ch. 112, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 15.1-1; Laws 1980, ch. 38, § 1; 1984, ch. 15, § 1; ch. 34, § 2; 2011, ch. 129, § 301.

The 2011 amendment, effective July 1, 2011, in the introductory language of (a) and in (a)(xv), substituted “15-11-302” for “15-10-117.”

Editor's notes. —

There is no subsection (b) in this section as it appears in the printed acts.

Authority to engage in collective bargaining. —

City's mayor and/or single council member could not negotiate with a firefighters' union because the mayor and/or single council member were not “corporate authorities,” with wage setting authority, so city council was required to negotiate with the union. Int'l Ass'n of Firefighters Local Union No. 279 v. City of Cheyenne, 2013 WY 157, 316 P.3d 1162, 2013 Wyo. LEXIS 163 (Wyo. 2013).

Convictions in municipal courts for driving while intoxicated are for violations of ordinances and not of state statutes, even if the state statute is copied verbatim in the ordinance or if it is adopted as the ordinance by reference. State ex rel. Motor Vehicle Div. v. Holtz, 674 P.2d 732, 1983 Wyo. LEXIS 394 (Wyo. 1983).

Quoted in

Carlson v. Bratton, 681 P.2d 1333, 1984 Wyo. LEXIS 291 (Wyo. 1984).

Cited in

Collier v. Hilltop Nat'l Bank, 920 P.2d 1241, 1996 Wyo. LEXIS 99 (Wyo. 1996).

§ 15-1-102. Prior incorporations and elections legalized.

All incorporations and proceedings to incorporate cities and towns and all elections held in cities and towns, whether pursuant to the laws of the territory of Wyoming, or the state of Wyoming, are legalized, notwithstanding any irregularity that may have occurred.

History. Laws 1965, ch. 112, § 2; W.S. 1957, § 15.1-2; Laws 1980, ch. 38, § 1.

§ 15-1-103. General powers of governing bodies.

  1. The governing bodies of all cities and towns may:
    1. Sue and be sued;
    2. Have and use a common seal;
    3. Purchase and hold real and personal property for their use including real estate sold for taxes;
    4. Sell, convey and lease any estate owned and make any orders respecting it deemed to be in their best interest;
    5. Perform all acts in relation to the property and concerns of the city or town necessary to the exercise of its corporate powers;
    6. Receive bequests, gifts and donations of all kinds of property in fee simple, or in trust for public, charitable or other purposes and do all things necessary to carry out their intended purpose;
    7. Control the finances of the corporation, including providing by ordinance for:
      1. The preparation, maintenance and retention of required records and accounts;
      2. Any required reports to the director of the state department of audit’s office; and
      3. If deemed necessary the preparation of independent audits of the financial condition of the city or town, which shall be conducted by a certified public accountant or a public accountant who has been in the practice of public accounting for a period of five (5) years as a principal.
    8. Appropriate money by ordinance only and pay all necessary expenses, including supplies, salaries of employees and debts;
    9. Levy and collect special assessments against persons or property to the extent allowed by the constitution and the law;
    10. Borrow money on the credit of the corporation for corporate purposes as allowed by the constitution and the laws and issue warrants and bonds therefor in such amounts and forms and on such conditions as they determine;
    11. Take all necessary action to plan, construct or otherwise improve, modify, repair, maintain and regulate the use of streets, including the regulation of any structures thereunder, alleys, any bridges, parks, public grounds, cemeteries and sidewalks;
    12. In the manner provided in W.S. 15-7-301 through 15-7-305 vacate from public use any property acquired or held for park purposes, if:
      1. through (C) Repealed by Laws 1984, ch. 15, § 2.
    13. License, tax and regulate any business whatsoever conducted or trafficked in within the limits of the city or town for the purpose of raising revenue, and any license taxes imposed shall be uniform in respect to the class of business upon which imposed;
    14. Regulate or prohibit the running at large within the city limits of any animals, impose a license fee for the keeping or harboring of dogs and establish and provide for the operation of a pound;
    15. Regulate, license, tax or prohibit saloons and shooting galleries or places;
    16. Suppress or prohibit:
      1. All gambling games or devices except antique gambling devices as defined in W.S. 6-7-101(a)(x) and authorize the destruction thereof;
      2. Houses of prostitution and other disorderly houses and punish the keeper thereof and persons resorting thereto; and
      3. Other disorderly and vicious practices or conduct.
    17. Restrain and punish vagrants, mendicants and prostitutes;
    18. Regulate, prevent or suppress riots, disturbances, disorderly assemblies or parades, or any other conduct which disturbs or jeopardizes the public health, safety, peace or morality, in any public or private place;
    19. Declare and abate nuisances and impose fines upon parties who create, continue or permit nuisances to exist;
    20. Compel the attendance of witnesses for the investigation of matters before it and the presiding officer may administer the requisite oaths;
    21. Purchase, lease or rent land within or without the corporate limits for the deposit of refuse matter, govern the use of the land and make reasonable rules and requirements for hauling refuse;
    22. Establish and regulate parks, zoological gardens and recreation areas within the city limits and upon land owned, leased or controlled outside of the city limits provided:
      1. The municipal court of the city or town has jurisdiction to punish any violator of the ordinances of the city or town governing those areas;
      2. The state game and fish commission is authorized to furnish to any city or town any game or animals requested, and the city or town shall pay the necessary expenses.
    23. Provide for the organization, support and equipping of a fire department and:
      1. Prescribe rules, regulations and penalties for governing the department;
      2. Establish regulations for the prevention of and extinguishing of fires;
      3. Make cooperative agreements or execute contracts for fire protection in accordance with W.S. 15-1-121.
    24. Prevent the dangerous construction and condition of chimneys, fireplaces and any other heating appliance or apparatus used in and about dwellings, factories and other buildings, and cause any such dangerous condition or appliance to be removed or replaced in a safe condition, regulate and prevent the carrying on of manufacturing likely to cause fires and prevent the deposit of ashes in unsafe places;
    25. Prescribe the thickness, strength and manner of constructing any buildings and the construction of fire escapes therein, and provide for their inspection;
    26. Provide for the repair, removal or destruction of any dangerous building or enclosure;
    27. Define fire limits and prescribe limits within which no building may be constructed except of brick, stone, or other incombustible material, without permission and cause the destruction or removal of any building constructed or repaired in violation of any ordinance;
    28. Regulate or prevent the storage, use and transportation of any combustible or explosive material within the corporate limits or within a given distance thereof;
    29. Appoint a board of health and prescribe its powers and duties and:
      1. Establish quarantine ordinances;
      2. Own and regulate convalescent homes, rest homes and hospitals;
      3. Contract for treatment and preventive services for the mentally ill, substance abuser and developmentally disabled as provided in W.S. 35-1-611 through 35-1-628.
    30. Divide the city or town into suitable districts for establishing a system of drainage including surface water drainage, sanitary sewers and water mains and:
      1. Provide and regulate the construction, repair and use of sewers and drains;
      2. Provide penalties for violations of regulations;
      3. Assess against the property concerned any penalty or costs and expenses in compliance with regulations.
    31. Take any action to establish, alter and regulate as deemed necessary the channels of streams, water courses and any other public water sources or supplies within the city;
    32. Establish, maintain and in a manner the governing body determines provide for the housing of public libraries and reading rooms and in connection therewith or separately public museums and:
      1. Purchase books and other appropriate material;
      2. Purchase and receive as gifts or on loan any books, pictures, articles or artifacts relating to the history, resources and development of the United States and its parts and lands;
      3. Place a museum temporarily in charge of donors; and
      4. Receive donations and bequests for the museum, in trust or otherwise, and make contracts and regulations for the care, protection and government thereof.
    33. Grant franchises for such terms as the governing body deems proper to any utility company, and, for communication companies, in accordance with W.S. 15-1-131, provided no franchise may be entered into with any person in which that person is given an exclusive right for any purpose whatsoever and:
      1. Grant to any franchisee utility company the privilege to install and maintain necessary installations under or over any streets, alleys or avenues;
      2. Contract for a specified time period with any franchisee electric light or gas company for the necessary energy and service for the lighting of streets, public buildings or other requirements of the city or town;
      3. Upon renewal or initial grant or renewal after condemnation of a franchise, may provide in the franchise that the franchisee shall furnish a gas distribution system through which any supplier, including the franchisee, may sell and distribute natural gas as provided by subsection (b) of this section, to any person served by the distribution system, provided that before any city or town implements this subparagraph, the question of whether or not to do so shall be submitted to and approved by a majority of the electors of the city or town voting on the question at a one-time election called for that purpose.
    34. Establish and regulate a police department, pass ordinances relating to the department and adopt job descriptions for all department personnel;
    35. Exercise the power of eminent domain and take property for public use within and without the city limits for any necessary or authorized public purpose as defined by W.S. 1-26-801(c);
    36. Require all buildings to be numbered by the owners, lessees, occupants or agents and in case of failure to comply with such requirements, cause the numbering to be done and assess the costs against the property or premises numbered;
    37. In addition to the appointed officers and employees provided by law, establish other positions as are necessary for the efficient operation of the city or town and:
      1. Prescribe duties and rules of all appointees;
      2. Determine working conditions or pay scales and supplementary benefits, as long as those provisions are not in conflict with existing statutes;
      3. During an emergency or special conditions warranting, make additional temporary appointments;
      4. Specify by ordinance that if any person is removed from office for incompetency, neglect of duty or otherwise for cause, the charges against that person shall be specified and the person removed shall be provided an opportunity for a hearing on the charges under procedures established in the ordinance;
      5. Make the cause of removal a matter of record.
    38. Cause compilations, codifications and comprehensive revisions to be made of all ordinances in force and provide for their distribution, sale and exchange;
    39. Lease lands owned or possessed outside the corporate limits which contain caves, caverns, or other natural formations to any person for the development and use of the natural formations on terms and conditions approved by the governing body;
    40. With written permission of the landowner or governmental agency involved, reclaim for beneficial use substandard lands by filling excavations and other depressions with refuse from the cities and towns, provided the deposit of refuse and the reclamation of the lands shall be done in a manner approved by the landowner, adjoining landowners and in accordance with any applicable laws or ordinances;
    41. Adopt ordinances, resolutions and regulations, including regulations not in conflict with this act and necessary for the health, safety and welfare of the city or town, necessary to give effect to the powers conferred by this act and, except as provided by paragraph (xlvi) of this subsection, enforce all ordinances by imposing fines not exceeding seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00), or imprisonment not exceeding six (6) months, or both. The governing body of a city or town may by ordinance impose a term of probation for battery which may exceed the maximum term of imprisonment established for the offense provided the term of probation, together with any extension thereof, shall in no case exceed one (1) year;
    42. Subject to subsection (d) of this section, take any action necessary to acquire any needed or useful property, or to construct, maintain, repair or replace any lawful improvement, development, project or other activity of any kind, or to participate, join or cooperate with other governments or political subdivisions, or departments or agencies thereof, for which funds may be borrowed from, granted or made available in whole or in part, on a matching basis or otherwise, by the United States of America or the state of Wyoming, or any subdivision, department or agency of either;
    43. License and regulate pawnbrokers and junk or secondhand dealers and provide for the examination of premises and business property of such persons pursuant to law for the purpose of discovering stolen property;
    44. Take into custody abandoned, or junk motor vehicles and parts or remains thereof which are nuisances and are on public property or on public streets, alleys and ways and:
      1. Remove and store the vehicles or parts at the expense of the owner;
      2. Permit redemption of the vehicles or parts;
      3. If not redeemed after giving public notice sell the vehicles or parts without warranty;
      4. Pay expenses from the sale; and
      5. After lapse of a reasonable length of time, deposit unclaimed proceeds from the sale of vehicles or parts into the general fund of the municipality.
    45. Contract with nonprofit corporations, hospitals and clinics to provide human services for persons within its jurisdiction;
    46. Adopt ordinances establishing pretreatment standards and requirements for municipal waste water collection systems and provide for enforcement of the standards and requirements through:
      1. Injunctive relief; and
      2. The assessment against industrial users of civil or criminal penalties for violations of, or noncompliance with, the pretreatment standards and requirements, provided the civil penalty shall not be less than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) and shall not exceed ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) a day for each day of violation. The proceeds of any civil penalty imposed by a district court under any ordinance adopted pursuant to this paragraph shall be deposited in the general fund of the city or town.
    47. By ordinance, prohibit or authorize and regulate the operation of golf carts as defined under W.S. 31-5-102(a)(lxi) on public streets and roadways within the corporate boundaries of the city or town;
    48. Repealed by Laws 1999, ch. 22, § 2.
    49. Unless specifically prohibited by statute, accept negotiable paper in payment of any tax, assessment, license, permit, fee, fine or other money owing to the city or town or collectible by the city or town on behalf of the state or other unit of government, or in payment of any bail deposit or other trust deposit. As used in this paragraph, negotiable paper means money orders, paper arising from the use of a lender credit card as defined in W.S. 40-14-140(a)(ix), checks and drafts, including, without limitation, sales drafts and checks and drafts signed by a holder of a lender credit card issued by a bank maintaining a revolving loan account as defined in W.S. 40-14-308, for lender credit card holders. The acceptance of negotiable paper by the governing body under this subsection shall be in accordance with and subject to the same terms and conditions provided by W.S. 18-3-505. Any fees assessed for processing a credit card payment may be borne by the governing body of the city or town or person tendering payment. Any fees assessed for processing a credit card payment collected on behalf of the state shall be borne by the governing body of the city or town or person tendering payment and not by the state;
    50. Appoint special municipal officers, who are not certified as peace officers, to issue citations to individuals for the limited purpose of enforcing ordinances, resolutions and regulations in the areas of animal control, parking and municipal code enforcement. Special municipal officers are not law enforcement officers:
      1. For purposes of employee benefits provided in title 9 of Wyoming statutes;
      2. Are not peace officers for purposes of title 6 or title 7 of Wyoming statutes;
      3. Are not peace officers for purposes of W.S. 1-39-112;
      4. Shall not be required to carry a firearm;
      5. Shall not have the power of arrest;
      6. Shall not be issued a peace officer’s badge; and
      7. Shall not represent themselves to be peace officers.
  2. Any franchise granted pursuant to subparagraph (a)(xxxiii)(C) of this section is subject to the following:
    1. The franchise agreement shall specify who is responsible for deliverability;
    2. The distribution system shall continue to be a public utility whose charges are regulated by the public service commission. The charges shall reflect the reasonable nongas costs subject to management audit as the public service commission deems necessary plus a reasonable return on investment;
    3. Any city or town or its authorized representative shall act as an agent for any person served by the system in negotiating terms and conditions for the supply of natural gas to that person, and the franchisee distribution system shall accept for delivery to any person served by the system, natural gas from any supplier;
    4. The public service commission shall designate a place or places in the vicinity of the distribution system for the acceptance of natural gas not supplied by franchisee;
    5. The public service commission shall adopt and enforce minimum quality standards for all gas delivered to the distribution system. These standards shall reflect the practices of the operators of the distribution system unless good cause is shown for different standards. The standards shall be designed to facilitate the commingling of gas from different suppliers;
    6. As soon as there are at least two (2) suppliers offering natural gas to all customers served by the franchisee and as soon as the additional supplier or suppliers are capable of delivering gas in at least one-third (1/3) of the volume required by the entire distribution system provided that the public service commission finds that the suppliers own or control, and have committed to guaranteed delivery, reserves of natural gas sufficient to supply ten (10) years of demand at that level, then all persons supplying gas shall have the authority to set their own prices. The proposed supplier has the burden of proving adequate reserves and deliverability. The Wyoming oil and gas commission shall report to the public service commission on the adequacy and deliverability when a utility gas supply is proposed to be displaced under this act;
    7. Subject to the availability of pipeline capacity and the requirements of federal law and regulations the public service commission may, after notice and hearing if necessary, designate any point in the state on a gas pipeline operated for the purpose of delivering gas to the distribution system or its parent or subsidiary company as a point for receipt of gas to the system and regulate the charges for shipping gas from that point to the system. If a pipeline has insufficient capacity the public service commission consistent with W.S. 30-5-125 may require it to accept gas that has a lower price to the consumer in preference to higher price gas. The public service commission may impose any conditions or requirements pursuant to this subsection that are necessary to protect the public health, safety and welfare, to ensure the efficient operation of the natural gas distribution and supply system and to ensure the lowest possible price to retail customers, including but not limited to proper assignment of costs of connecting suppliers to the system;
    8. When a city renews or grants a franchise for the supply of natural gas under subparagraph (a)(xxxiii)(C) of this section, the public service commission may require that the distribution of gas in surrounding unincorporated areas also be made subject to the terms of the same franchise;
    9. If a distribution system has only one (1) supplier of natural gas all prices charged in that franchise are subject to W.S. 37-2-121 and 37-2-122;
    10. All suppliers of gas to the distribution system shall annually report to the public service commission the annual consumption of natural gas by their customers of record at the date of the report and their natural gas reserves. If their natural gas reserves are less than a five (5) year supply, the public service commission may forbid any supplier from serving new customers until the reserves are equal to a five (5) year supply for all customers;
    11. Any supplier entering the system under this subsection is liable for injuries, damages or other losses to the extent to which the injuries, damages or other losses are proximately caused by the supplier’s operations within the system and are due to failure of the supplier to exercise that standard of care which a reasonable, prudent person would exercise under the same or similar circumstances to avoid an undue risk of harm or are due to the supplier’s failure to deliver contracted amounts of natural gas.
  3. Any provision in a gas purchase contract which contains or creates an indefinite escalator clause, otherwise known as a “favored nation treaty” provision, is contrary to the public policy of the state and is void and unenforceable if:
    1. The contract is to sell gas to the holders of a municipality franchise which supplies retail customers in the state;
    2. The contract provides for the sale in the state of gas produced within the state;
    3. The contract gas price is in excess of the general market price which would otherwise exist in the absence of the indefinite escalator clause; and
    4. The higher price resulting from the application of the escalator clause is not required by any enforceable provision of statutes or regulations enacted or adopted pursuant to the Natural Gas Policy Act of 1978 or other appropriate statutes and regulations of the United States.
  4. Before the governing body of a city or town enters into an agreement to borrow money from the United States of America or from the state of Wyoming, or from any subdivision, agency or department of either, to fund a public improvement project to be repaid solely from revenues generated by the enterprise with which the financed project is associated, the proposal to enter into the loan agreement shall be submitted to and approved by the electors of the city or town in the same manner and pursuant to the same procedures as provided for bond issues under the Political Subdivision Bond Election Law, if the total amount to be borrowed for the project exceeds the greater of:
    1. Five million dollars ($5,000,000.00); or
    2. An amount calculated by multiplying the number of individuals to be served by the proposed public improvement project times one thousand two hundred dollars ($1,200.00).

(D) The city or town has held title to the property for more than ten (10) years and no substantial use has been made thereof for park purposes; or

(E) The property will be used for public school or public educational purposes after the vacation.

History. Laws 1965, ch. 112, § 3; W.S. 1957, § 15.1-3; Laws 1967, ch. 117, § 1; ch. 151, § 1; 1969, ch. 120, § 1; 1973, ch. 206, § 1; 1977, ch. 45, § 4; 1979, ch. 85, § 1; ch. 155, § 2; 1980, ch. 38, § 1; 1981, ch. 101, § 1; ch. 174, § 2; 1984, ch. 15, § 1; ch. 34, § 2; 1985, ch. 172, §§ 1, 3; 1991, ch. 206, § 1; ch. 215, § 1; ch. 240, § 1; 1995, ch. 118, § 2; 1996, ch. 75, § 1; 1997, ch. 59, § 1; 1998, ch. 84, § 1; 1999, ch. 22, §§ 1, 2; ch. 107, § 1; 2004, ch. 42, § 1; ch. 130, § 1; 2007, ch. 50, § 1; ch. 67, § 1; ch. 139, § 2; 2009, ch. 138, § 1; 2020 ch. 85, § 2, effective July 1, 2020.

Cross references. —

For authority of mayor to enforce health ordinances within five miles of corporate limits of city, see § 15-3-202.

As to public parks generally, see §§ 15-7-301 to 15-7-305.

As to waterworks franchises to private corporations, see §§ 15-7-701 to 15-7-708.

As to urban renewal, see §§ 15-9-101 to 15-9-137.

As to housing, see §§ 15-10-101 to 15-10-117.

As to officers authorized to administer oaths generally, see § 1-2-102.

As to eminent domain generally, see §§ 1-26-501 through 1-26-817 and Rule 71.1, W.R.C.P.

As to public indecency, see § 6-4-201.

As to disturbances of public order, see § 6-6-101 et seq.

As to offenses tending to breach the peace, see §§ 6-6-101 to 6-6-307.

As to nuisances, see §§ 6-6-201 through 6-6-209.

As to weapons offenses, see § 6-8-101 et seq.

As to power of cities and towns to require tuberculin tests of dairy cattle, see § 11-19-205.

As to prohibition against swine, goats or domestic elk running at large, see § 11-26-101.

As to dogs generally, see §§ 11-31-102 through 11-31-108.

As to municipal and district health departments generally, see §§ 35-1-301 to 35-1-309.

As to the division of community programs of the department of health and the treatment of mental illness and other disabilities, see §§ 35-1-611 to 35-1-628 and notes thereto.

As to communicable diseases generally, see §§ 35-4-101 to 35-4-139.

For additional authority of cities and towns to regulate nuisances, see § 35-10-408.

The 2004 amendments. —

The first 2004 amendment, by ch. 42, § 1, in (a)(xxii)(A), substituted “municipal court” for “police court.”

Laws 2004, ch. 42, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 3, 2004.

The second 2004 amendment, by ch. 130, § 1, in (a)(xxix)(C), substituted “35-1-628” for “35-1-625”; and in (a)(xli) inserted “of this subsection” following “provided by paragraph (xlvi).”

Laws 2004, ch. 130, § 4, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 19, 2004.

See the conflicting legislation note. This section has been set out incorporating changes made by both 2004 acts.

The 2007 amendments. —

The first 2007 amendment by ch. 50, § 1, effective July 1, 2007, added (a)(l).

The second 2007 amendment, by ch. 67, § 1, effective July 1, 2007, in (a)(xii), added (E), redesignated part of the existing provisions of (xii) as (D), and made related changes.

The third 2007 amendment, by ch. 139, § 2, effective July 1, 2007, inserted “as defined by W.S. 1-26-801(c)” in (a)(xxxv).

While none of the amendments gave effect to the others, all have been set out as above.

The 2009 amendment, effective July 1, 2009, in (a)(xv), deleted “pool halls, any tables kept for hire, bowling alleys” preceding “and shooting galleries.”

The 2020 amendment, effective July 1, 2020, in the introductory language of (a)(xxxiii) added “and, for communication companies, in accordance with W.S. 15-1-131” following “any utility company.”

Natural Gas Policy Act. —

The Natural Gas Policy Act of 1978, referred to in subsection (c)(iv), is found at 15 U.S.C. § 3301 et seq.

Meaning of “this act.” —

For definition of “this act,” referred to in this section, see § 15-1-101(a)(xv).

Conflicting legislation. —

Laws 2004, ch. 130, § 3, provides: “Any other act adopted by the Wyoming legislature during the same session in which this act is adopted shall be given precedence and shall prevail over the amendments in this act to the extent that such acts are in conflict with this act.”

Cities have only such powers as are granted by legislature, and they cannot challenge the legality of legislation passed by their creators. Wyoming State Treas. v. City of Rawlins, 510 P.2d 301, 1973 Wyo. LEXIS 160 (Wyo. 1973).

Municipalities can exercise only those powers of government which are expressly or impliedly conferred. City of Buffalo v. Joslyn, 527 P.2d 1106, 1974 Wyo. LEXIS 245 (Wyo. 1974).

And section does not alter general rule. —

Subsection 29 of former § 15-160, W.S. 1957 (similar to subsection (a)(xli) of this section), did not liberalize general rule that municipality possesses powers which are necessarily or fairly implied from powers expressly granted. Whipps v. Greybull, 56 Wyo. 355, 109 P.2d 805, 1941 Wyo. LEXIS 5 (Wyo. 1941).

Anti-abortion demonstration activities. —

Town sought to restrict an anti-abortion organization's demonstration activities in and around the town square during the Boy Scouts' annual Elk Fest. The town's asserted interest in protecting its youth gave it a sufficient stake in the outcome of the proceedings to allow it standing to bring an ex parte petition for a temporary restraining order against the organization. Operation Save Am. v. City of Jackson, 2012 WY 51, 275 P.3d 438, 2012 Wyo. LEXIS 54 (Wyo. 2012).

Fireworks. —

Nothing in the amended § 35-10-205 or the relatively newly enacted § 35-10-208 does damage to the fundamental proposition that the sales and use of fireworks may be regulated by cities within five miles of the city limits. Ford v. City of Riverton, 919 P.2d 636, 1996 Wyo. LEXIS 96 (Wyo. 1996).

Fixed rate formula in power contract held reasonable. —

Fixed rate formula agreed upon in a power contract between municipalities organizing an agency under the Wyoming Joint Powers Act, §§ 16-1-102 through 16-1-109, to produce and distribute electric power to their inhabitants was reasonable. Frank v. Cody, 572 P.2d 1106, 1977 Wyo. LEXIS 304 (Wyo. 1977).

Limited grant of franchise to utility. —

Even if a city may lawfully grant some franchise to a utility outside its city limits, it cannot be of any exclusive nature precluding it from extending its own lines into its own subdivisions, regularly annexed. Tri-County Elec. Ass'n v. Gillette, 584 P.2d 995, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 227 (Wyo. 1978) (decided prior to 1980 revision).

Ordinance imposing penalties upon gas utilities operating without license or franchise was void and could not be sustained under any residual police power of the city. K N Energy, Inc. v. Casper, 755 P.2d 207, 1988 Wyo. LEXIS 78 (Wyo. 1988).

Procedure for condemnation by city prescribed by rules. —

A city has authority to exercise the right of eminent domain under paragraph (xxxv) of subsection (a); however, the procedure for condemnation provided by that paragraph has been superseded by later legislative enactment prescribing that Rule 71.1, W.R.C.P. will be followed. Tri-County Elec. Ass'n v. City of Gillette, 584 P.2d 995, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 227 (Wyo. 1978). See § 1-26-501.

Acquisition of land for federal agency by public subscription not ultra vires. —

A town did not commit an ultra vires act where it acquired title to a tract of land with money raised by public subscription for the benefit of a federal agency in exchange for $75,000.00 credit on a sewer system for the entire town. Amick v. Elwood, 77 Wyo. 269, 314 P.2d 944, 1957 Wyo. LEXIS 24 (Wyo. 1957) (decided under former § 15-160, W.S. 1957).

Borrowing for light and power plant. —

Town council, without approval by vote of the people, does not have authority to borrow money to pay for municipal light and power plant and to issue bonds payable solely from revenues accruing from operation of plant. Whipps v. Greybull, 56 Wyo. 355, 109 P.2d 805, 1941 Wyo. LEXIS 5 (Wyo. 1941).

Power to construct public utility plant and to borrow large sum of money necessary to pay for it cannot reasonably be implied from power to provide for lighting streets and erection of lampposts. Whipps v. Greybull, 56 Wyo. 355, 109 P.2d 805, 1941 Wyo. LEXIS 5 (Wyo. 1941).

Act of 1907 authorizing municipalities to construct light and power plants granted new power and was not merely providing method of exercising power that already existed. Whipps v. Greybull, 56 Wyo. 355, 109 P.2d 805, 1941 Wyo. LEXIS 5 (Wyo. 1941).

Borrowing for water project. —

Legislature did not intend for financing of municipal water project to be considered a “bond,” and therefore there was no statutory requirement for an election prior to town's incurring debt. Cooper v. Town of Pinedale, 1 P.3d 1197, 2000 Wyo. LEXIS 74 (Wyo. 2000).

Taxation of each lot as stated amount. —

Town council held not authorized to pass ordinance taxing each lot a stated amount, regardless of value, to furnish water for irrigation. Town Council of Hudson v. Board of Comm'rs, 37 Wyo. 160, 259 P. 1051, 1927 Wyo. LEXIS 74 (Wyo. 1927).

Provision of ordinance regulating barbershops, providing that shops must open not earlier than 8 a.m. and close not later than 6 p.m., held unreasonable and void. State ex rel. Newman v. City of Laramie, 40 Wyo. 74, 275 P. 106, 1929 Wyo. LEXIS 22 (1929).

Park-land dedication ordinances. —

The broad powers delegated by the legislature can fairly encompass the power to adopt a park-land dedication ordinance. A city can require the payment of a sum in lieu of park-land dedication in order to lessen the impact and pressure on park facilities that results from the influx of inhabitants caused by a new development. The limitation on this power is the requirement that any fees collected in lieu of land dedication must be earmarked to accounts for the purpose of acquiring needed park land and maintenance of existing park facilities. Coulter v. Rawlins, 662 P.2d 888, 1983 Wyo. LEXIS 311 (Wyo. 1983).

Territorial scope of ordinance's effect for health purposes. —

For health purposes, a city may make an ordinance effective for a distance of five miles beyond the city limits. Haddenham v. Laramie, 648 P.2d 551, 1982 Wyo. LEXIS 362 (Wyo. 1982).

City without power to establish highway through park where no express legislative authority given. —

Where land owned by city had been dedicated by it for park purposes and there was not express authority from the legislature to establish a highway through the park, the city was without power to do so since the property was held by the city for the benefit of the people as a whole. They were represented by the legislature which had sole authority concerning it. Rayor v. Cheyenne, 63 Wyo. 72, 178 P.2d 115, 1947 Wyo. LEXIS 5 (Wyo. 1947).

Estoppel to deny validity of street vacation. —

Where a town, in consideration of a lot owner's waiver of his rights under a contract to another tract of land, vacated a part of the street in front of his lots, and had built a public library on the property surrendered by him, so that it could not restore his former situation, it is estopped to deny validity of the vacation of the street. Rohrbaugh v. Mokler, 26 Wyo. 514, 188 P. 448, 1920 Wyo. LEXIS 14 (Wyo. 1920).

Defects in streets. —

Towns, having exclusive control of streets, are liable for damages resulting from failure to use reasonable care in keeping them in reasonably safe condition for public travel, and in safeguarding, by proper signal, places of danger thereon. Opitz v. Newcastle, 35 Wyo. 358, 249 P. 799, 1926 Wyo. LEXIS 23 (Wyo. 1926).

City may levy occupation tax. —

Subsection (a)(xiii) authorized city to pass an ordinance levying an occupation tax, and the fact that this section omitted the phrase “for purpose of raising revenue” will not negate that authority. City of Rawlins v. Frontier Ref. Co., 396 P.2d 740, 1964 Wyo. LEXIS 128 (Wyo. 1964).

Description of tax. —

Where license tax imposed by ordinance was purely for revenue purposes, city claiming no right under its police power to regulate defendant's business, and required license, as a receipt for tax, being only an incident, a reference in the statute and ordinance to the tax as a “license tax,” instead of denominating it an “excise,” “occupation,” or “privilege” tax, was immaterial. City of Sheridan v. Litman, 32 Wyo. 14, 228 P. 628, 1924 Wyo. LEXIS 43 (Wyo. 1924).

Regulation may not violate commerce clause nor discriminate against nonresidents. —

A town ordinance prohibiting nonresident persons from selling by sample and taking orders for the goods of their principals, to be delivered in the town, without first procuring a license, by providing that the ordinance shall not apply to those who sell exclusively to regular merchants of such town is in conflict with the United States constitution, conferring on congress power to regulate commerce among the states; and is void as discrimination against nonresidents of the state. Clements v. Town of Casper, 4 Wyo. 494, 35 P. 472, 1894 Wyo. LEXIS 5 (1894).

But nuisances may be abated. —

Municipalities have authority to decide what constitutes nuisances and to abate and punish under ordinances prescribing such nuisances. Town of Green River v. Fuller Brush Co., 65 F.2d 112, 1933 U.S. App. LEXIS 2934 (10th Cir. Wyo. 1933).

Including practice of going in private residences to sell goods. —

An ordinance declaring that the practice of going in and upon private residences by solicitors, peddlers, itinerant merchants, etc., for the purpose of soliciting orders for, or selling goods, wares and merchandise, is a nuisance and imposing a penalty is valid, and not in violation of any constitutional or statutory provision. Town of Green River v. Bunger, 50 Wyo. 52, 58 P.2d 456, 1936 Wyo. LEXIS 14 (Wyo. 1936).

Allegation of possession of business license required. —

A petition for mandamus to compel the authorities to grant permission to change location of a licensed business, which also requires a county license, without alleging that county license is possessed for the new location is demurrable (now subject to a motion to dismiss. See Rule 12, W.R.C.P.). State v. Town Council, 25 Wyo. 211, 167 P. 982, 1917 Wyo. LEXIS 20 (1917).

Comparison of ordinance as to wandering cattle with common-law rule of liability. —

Under modern conditions there is a tendency to revert to the common-law rule of liability as to the damage done by wandering livestock, and this would be appropriately applied to a city passing an ordinance pursuant to subsection 16 of former § 15-686, W.S. 1957 (similar to subsection (a)(xiv) of this section), which would prohibit cattle from wandering at large in city limits. Sowers v. Corthell, 69 Wyo. 215, 240 P.2d 891, 1952 Wyo. LEXIS 3 (Wyo. 1952).

Sale of intoxicants. —

Any discretion of county commissioners as to issuing liquor license does not include right or power on part of commissioners to refuse issuance of license solely because of opposition to operation of liquor establishments, in view of this and other sections. State ex rel. Rehder v. Board of Comm'rs, 26 Wyo. 75, 177 P. 130, 1919 Wyo. LEXIS 1 (Wyo. 1919).

Condemnation statutes apply to damage to abutting property. —

Statutes authorizing condemnation by cities of first class apply both to property physically taken and to abutting property indirectly damaged even though some provisions relating to property actually taken cannot be carried out in the latter type of case. Hirt v. Casper, 56 Wyo. 57, 103 P.2d 394, 1940 Wyo. LEXIS 25 (Wyo. 1940).

Jury trial as to compensation. —

Owner of property condemned for waterworks has the right to a jury trial on the question of compensation, if demanded within the time prescribed by statute. City of Cheyenne v. Edwards, 22 Wyo. 401, 143 P. 356, 1914 Wyo. LEXIS 26 (Wyo. 1914).

Municipalities have full authority and control over public water and sewerage systems. Coulter v. Rawlins, 662 P.2d 888, 1983 Wyo. LEXIS 311 (Wyo. 1983).

Including levy of connection and maintenance charges. —

Wyoming statutory provisions grant a city the power to levy sewer and water connection charges and to charge users of the systems in order to pay the costs of maintaining, operating and expanding them. Coulter v. Rawlins, 662 P.2d 888, 1983 Wyo. LEXIS 311 (Wyo. 1983).

Local improvements include sewers. —

The power to make “local improvements” includes the power to construct and repair sanitary sewers. Henning v. Consolidated Bldg. & Loan Co., 50 Wyo. 315, 62 P.2d 540, 1936 Wyo. LEXIS 32 (Wyo. 1936) (decided under former law).

Kinds of sewers. —

In absence of provisions limiting sewers to sanitary sewers, proposed storm ditch to carry off flood waters within city is authorized and general municipal bonds may be issued, since term “sewer” includes both storm and sanitary sewers. Anselmi v. Rock Springs, 53 Wyo. 223, 80 P.2d 419, 1938 Wyo. LEXIS 14 (Wyo. 1938) (decided under former law).

Appointment of temporary police “commander” held nullity absent emergency. —

Where there is more than sufficient evidence that the appointment of a police “commander” was not made as a temporary appointment and that an emergency did not exist, the appointment is a nullity. City of Rock Springs v. Police Protection Ass'n, 610 P.2d 975, 1980 Wyo. LEXIS 261 (Wyo. 1980).

Provision applicable to “at-will” employee. —

Subsection (a)(xxxvii), relating to positions necessary for the efficient operation of the city or town, was applicable to a municipal garbage man under an “at-will,” as opposed to a fixed-term, contract. Siebken v. Wheatland, 700 P.2d 1236, 1985 Wyo. LEXIS 490 (Wyo. 1985).

Discharge of a municipal garbage man was not in violation of this section under the following facts: (1) there was a rule against “scavenging” known to the employee prior to his discharge; (2) when the employee was discharged, he was informed of a complaint against him which caused the discharge, after which he requested a hearing before the town council, at which he presented his position, admitting that he removed material from garbage at other times and took it home; and (3) the town council took the matter under advisement and agreed that the discharge was proper. Siebken v. Wheatland, 700 P.2d 1236, 1985 Wyo. LEXIS 490 (Wyo. 1985).

Applied in

Nollsch v. City of Rock Springs, 724 P.2d 447, 1986 Wyo. LEXIS 603 (Wyo. 1986).

Quoted in

Neel v. City of Laramie, 488 P.2d 1056, 1971 Wyo. LEXIS 250 (Wyo. 1971); Carlson v. Bratton, 681 P.2d 1333, 1984 Wyo. LEXIS 291 (Wyo. 1984); Cheyenne Newspapers, Inc. v. City of Cheyenne, 2016 WY 125, 386 P.3d 329, 2016 Wyo. LEXIS 139 (Wyo. 2016).

Stated in

City Council v. Kreiling, 911 P.2d 1037, 1996 Wyo. LEXIS 24 (Wyo. 1996).

Cited in

Larsen v. City of Cheyenne, 626 P.2d 558, 1981 Wyo. LEXIS 318 (Wyo. 1981); Town of Marbleton v. Town of Big Piney, 719 P.2d 1389, 1986 Wyo. LEXIS 564 (Wyo. 1986); Kautza v. City of Cody, 812 P.2d 143, 1991 Wyo. LEXIS 102 (Wyo. 1991); City of Green River v. Debernardi Constr. Co., 816 P.2d 1287, 1991 Wyo. LEXIS 142 (Wyo. 1991); Deromedi v. Town of Thermopolis, 2002 WY 69, 45 P.3d 1150, 2002 Wyo. LEXIS 74 (Wyo. 2002); Tavern, LLC v. Town of Alpine, 2017 WY 56, 395 P.3d 167, 2017 Wyo. LEXIS 57 (Wyo. 2017).

Law reviews. —

See “Occupation Taxes and the Employee,” 3 Wyo. L.J. 242 (1949).

See “Administration of the General Property Tax in Wyoming,” 4 Wyo. L.J. 227.

For article, “Governmental Immunity from Damage Actions in Wyoming — Part II,” see VII Land & Water L. Rev. 617 (1972).

For article, “State Jurisdiction over the Regulation of Energy Distribution and Other Public Utility Services,” see XV Land & Water L. Rev. 535 (1980).

For comment, “Solar Access Rights in Wyoming,” see XIX Land & Water L. Rev. 419 (1984).

For article, “Goodbye 3-Card Monte: The Wyoming Criminal Code of 1982” (part two), see XIX Land & Water L. Rev. 509 (1984).

For article, “The Wyoming Natural Gas Consumers' Act of 1985: An Experiment in Controlling Natural Gas Prices and a Response to Indefinite Price Escalation Clauses,” see XXI Land & Water L. Rev. 141 (1986).

For case note, “Criminal Procedure — When Should a Jury Trial Be Required in the Wyoming Municipal Courts? City of Casper v. Cheatham, 739 P.2d 1222, 1987 Wyo. LEXIS 471 (Wyo. 1987),” see XXV Land & Water L. Rev. 611 (1990).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Validity of municipal regulation of solicitation of magazine subscriptions on streets, 9 ALR2d 728.

Public regulation and prohibition of sound amplifiers or loudspeaker broadcast in street, 10 ALR2d 627.

Granting or taking of lease by municipality as within authorization of purchase or acquisition thereof, 11 ALR2d 168.

Right of municipality or public to use of subsurface of street or highway for purpose other than sewers, pipes, conduits for wires, and the like, 11 ALR2d 180.

Exemption from taxation of municipally owned or operated stadium, auditorium and similar property, 16 ALR2d 1376.

Validity of regulations as to plumbers and plumbing, 22 ALR2d 816.

Compromise of claim for city taxes, 28 ALR2d 1425.

Release or compromise of city taxes by city attorney, 28 ALR2d 1425.

Capacity of municipality as trustee for maintenance or care of private cemetery, burial lot, tomb or monument, or erection of tomb or monument, 47 ALR2d 622.

Right to compel municipality to extend its water system, 48 ALR2d 1222.

Municipal power to condemn land for cemeteries, 54 ALR2d 1322.

Constitutionality of provisions for destruction of dogs running at large, 56 ALR2d 1024.

Exchange of real property, power of municipal corporation as to, 60 ALR2d 220.

Municipality's power to sell, lease or mortgage public utility plant or interest therein, 61 ALR2d 595.

Relative rights, as between municipality and abutting landowners, to minerals, oil and gas underlying streets, alleys or parks, 62 ALR2d 1311.

Validity of municipal regulation of storage or accumulation of lumber, straw, trash or similar inflammable material, 64 ALR2d 1040.

Right of state or its political subdivision to maintain action in another state for support and maintenance of defendant's child, parent or dependent in plaintiff's institution, 67 ALR2d 771.

Parking meters, permissible use of funds from, 83 ALR2d 625.

Pledging parking meter revenues as unlawful relinquishment of governmental power, 83 ALR2d 649.

Power of municipal corporation to submit to arbitration, 20 ALR3d 569.

Validity and construction of anti-water pollution statutes or ordinances, 32 ALR3d 215.

Power of eminent domain as between state and subdivision or agency thereof, or as between different subdivisions or agencies themselves, 35 ALR3d 1293.

Validity of municipal regulation of aircraft flight paths or altitudes, 36 ALR3d 1314.

Cost of substitute facilities as measure of compensation paid to state or municipality for condemnation of public property, 40 ALR3d 143.

Validity and construction of municipal ordinances regulating community antenna television service (CATV), 41 ALR3d 384.

Propriety of injunctive relief against diversion of water by municipal corporation or public utility, 42 ALR3d 426.

Validity and construction of state and municipal enactments regulating lobbying, 42 ALR3d 1046.

Validity and construction of statute or ordinance providing for repair or destruction of residential building by public authorities at owner's expense, 43 ALR3d 916.

Power of municipal corporation to limit exclusive use of designated lanes or streets to buses and taxicabs, 43 ALR3d 1374.

Estoppel of municipality as to encroachments upon public streets, 44 ALR3d 257.

Power of municipal corporation to lease or sublet property owned or leased by it, 47 ALR3d 19.

Standing of municipal corporation or other governmental body to attack zoning of land lying outside its borders, 49 ALR3d 1126.

Validity and construction of statute or ordinance forbidding treatment in health clubs or massage salons by person of the opposite sex, 51 ALR3d 936.

Validity of municipal regulation more restrictive than state regulation as to time for selling or serving intoxicating liquor, 51 ALR3d 1061.

Validity and construction of regulations dealing with misrepresentation in the sale of kosher food, 52 ALR3d 959.

Power of municipality to charge nonresidents higher fees than residents for use of municipal facilities, 57 ALR3d 998.

Validity of statute or ordinance making it an offense to consume or have alcoholic beverages in open package in motor vehicle, 57 ALR3d 1071.

Validity and construction of curfew statute, ordinance or proclamation, 59 ALR3d 321, 83 ALR4th 1056.

Right of municipality to refuse services provided by it to resident for failure of resident to pay for other unrelated services, 60 ALR3d 714.

Gambling: construction and application of state or municipal enactments relating to policy or numbers games, 70 ALR3d 897.

Liability for negligence in carrying out governmentally required inspection of motor vehicle, 70 ALR3d 1239.

Validity of regulation providing for reserved parking spaces or parking priority on publicly owned property for members of a designated group, 70 ALR3d 1323.

Validity and construction of statute or ordinance requiring return deposits on soft drink or similar containers, 73 ALR3d 1105.

Right of owner of land not originally taken or purchased as part of adjacent project to recover, on enlargement of project to include adjacent land, enhanced value of property by reason of proximity to original land, 95 ALR3d 752.

Bells, carillons and the like as nuisance, 95 ALR3d 1268.

Recovery of exemplary or punitive damages from municipal corporation, 1 ALR4th 448.

Liability, in motor vehicle-related cases, of governmental entity for injury or death resulting from design, construction, or failure to warn of narrow bridge, 2 ALR4th 635.

Validity and construction of statutes or ordinances prohibiting profanity or profane swearing or cursing, 5 ALR4th 956.

Right of municipal corporation to review of unfavorable decision in action or prosecution for violation of ordinance — modern status, 11 ALR4th 399.

Factors affecting award of operating certificate, franchise, or license under state cable television act, 15 ALR4th 961.

Validity of zoning or building regulations restricting mobile homes or trailers to established mobile home or trailer parks, 17 ALR4th 106.

Validity and construction of statute or ordinance protecting historical landmarks, 18 ALR4th 990.

Liability, in motor vehicle-related cases, of governmental entity for injury, death, or property damage resulting from defect or obstruction in shoulder of street or highway, 19 ALR4th 532.

State or municipal towing impounding, or destruction of motor vehicles parked or abandoned on streets or highways, 32 ALR4th 728.

Private improvement of land dedicated but not used as street as estopping public rights, 36 ALR4th 625.

Windmill as nuisance, 36 ALR4th 1159.

State and local regulation of private landowner's disposal of solid waste on own property, 37 ALR4th 635.

Liability of governmental entity to builder or developer for negligent issuance of building permit subsequently suspended or revoked, 41 ALR4th 99.

Construction of provisions of statute or ordinance governing occasion, time or manner of summary destruction of domestic animals by public authorities, 42 ALR4th 839.

Validity of state or municipal tax or license fee upon occupation of practicing law, 50 ALR4th 467.

Validity, construction and application of statutes or ordinances involved in prosecutions for possession of bookmaking paraphernalia, 51 ALR4th 796.

Validity, construction and effect of statute requiring consultation with, or approval of, local governmental unit prior to locating group home, halfway house or similar community residence for the mentally ill, 51 ALR4th 1096.

Validity, construction and application of statutes or ordinances involved in prosecutions for transmission of wagers or wagering information related to bookmaking, 53 ALR4th 801.

Landlord and tenant: violation of statute or ordinance requiring landlord to furnish specified facilities or service as ground of liability for injury resulting from tenant's attempt to deal with deficiency, 63 ALR4th 883.

State and local government liability for injury or death of bicyclist due to defect or obstruction in public bicycle path, 68 ALR4th 204.

Municipal liability for negligent fire inspection and subsequent enforcement, 69 ALR4th 739.

Liability of private landowner for vegetation obscuring view at highway or street intersection, 69 ALR4th 1092.

Validity and construction of statute, ordinance or regulation applying to specific dog breeds, such as “pit bulls” or “bull terriers,” 80 ALR4th 70.

Right of one governmental subdivision to challenge annexation proceedings by another such subdivision, 17 ALR5th 195.

Validity and construction of statute or ordinance requiring installation of automatic sprinklers, 63 ALR5th 517.

Effect of broadcaster's employment practices on renewal of broadcaster's television license, 57 ALR Fed 16.

Judicial review under § 16 of Noise Control Act of 1972 (42 USC § 4915) of action of Administrator of Environmental Protection Agency, 59 ALR Fed 705.

Closing or relocation of medical facility serving large numbers of minority citizens as violative of Title VI of Civil Rights Act of 1964 (42 USC § 2000d et seq.), 69 ALR Fed 588.

Validity, under federal constitution, of regulations, rules or statutes requiring random or mass drug testing of public employees or persons whose employment is regulated by state, local or federal government, 86 ALR Fed 420.

§ 15-1-104. Authority to carry liability insurance.

  1. Any city or town may carry liability insurance in an amount the governing body deems necessary. The insurance shall be:
    1. On standard policy forms approved by the state insurance commissioner;
    2. With companies authorized to do business in Wyoming;
    3. Paid out of the general fund of the city or town.

History. Laws 1965, ch. 112, § 4; W.S. 1957, § 15.1-4; Laws 1979, ch. 157, § 3; 1980, ch. 38, § 1.

Cross references. —

For substantive provisions on governmental tort liability, see Wyoming Governmental Claims Act (§ 1-39-101 et seq.).

Editor's notes. —

There is no subsection (b) in this section as it appears in the printed acts.

Purchase of liability insurance is a waiver of tort immunity, at least up to the amount of the coverage. Collins v. Memorial Hosp., 521 P.2d 1339, 1974 Wyo. LEXIS 202 (Wyo. 1974).

Cited in

Lutheran Hosps. & Homes Soc'y of America v. Yepsen, 469 P.2d 409, 1970 Wyo. LEXIS 173 (Wyo. 1970).

Law reviews. —

For article, “Municipal Tort Liability: Purchase of Liability Insurance as a Waiver of Immunity,” see 18 Wyo. L.J. 220 (1964).

For case note on Lutheran Hosps. & Homes Soc'y of America v. Yepsen, 469 P.2d 409, 1970 Wyo. LEXIS 173 (Wyo. 1970), see VII Land & Water L. Rev. 717 (1972).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Liability or indemnity insurance carried by governmental unit as affecting immunity from tort liability, 68 ALR2d 1437.

Validity and construction of statute authorizing or requiring governmental unit to procure liability insurance covering public officers or employees for liability arising out of performance of public duties, 71 ALR3d 6.

Scope of provision in liability policy issued to municipal corporation or similar governmental body limiting coverage to injuries arising out of construction, maintenance or repair work, 30 ALR5th 699.

§ 15-1-105. Governing bodies; meetings; quorum; executive sessions.

Public meetings of the governing body shall be held in accordance with W.S. 16-4-401 through 16-4-408. Special meetings may also be called by a majority of the qualified members of the governing body. A majority of all the qualified members of the governing body constitutes a quorum for the transaction of business, but any number may adjourn a meeting to compel the attendance of and punish absent members. If the nature of the business so requires, the governing body by a vote of two-thirds (2/3) of the members present, may go into executive session and exclude the public therefrom.

History. Laws 1965, ch. 112, § 5; W.S. 1957, § 15.1-5; Laws 1980, ch. 38, § 1; 1984, ch. 15, § 1; ch. 34, § 2; 2005, ch. 194, § 2.

The 2005 amendment, effective July 1, 2005, substituted “16-4-408” for “16-4-407.”

Cross references. —

As to ordinances and resolutions, see §§ 15-1-114 to 15-1-119.

As to mayor's messages in first class cities, see § 15-3-202.

As to president of governing body in first class cities, see § 15-3-203.

As to governing body of cities operating under commission form of government, see §§ 15-4-101 and 15-4-102.

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Validity, construction and application of statutes making public proceedings open to the public, 38 ALR3d 1070, 34 ALR5th 591.

Abstention from voting of member of municipal council present at session as affecting requisite voting majority, 63 ALR3d 1072.

Emergency exception under state law making proceedings by public bodies open to the public, 33 ALR5th 731.

Attorney-client exception under state law making proceedings by public bodies open to the public, 34 ALR5th 591.

§ 15-1-106. Conduct and journal of governing body's proceedings.

The governing body shall determine the rules for the conduct of its proceedings, and shall keep a journal thereof which is a public record. The manner in which each member of the governing body votes on any matter upon which a vote is taken shall be entered in the journal.

History. Laws 1965, ch. 112, § 6; W.S. 1957, § 15.1-6; Laws 1980, ch. 38, § 1; 1984, ch. 15, § 1.

§ 15-1-107. Vacancies in offices; grounds; how filled.

  1. A vacancy exists in the office of mayor or councilman if during the term for which elected any mayor or councilman:
    1. Except as provided in W.S. 22-23-103, fails the residency requirements as defined by local ordinance for the city, town or ward;
    2. Is convicted of a felony;
    3. Fails to attend four (4) or more consecutive regularly scheduled meetings of the council without an excused absence as determined by a majority of the council according to procedures adopted pursuant to subsection (b) of this section; or
    4. Meets any other condition specified in W.S. 22-18-101.
  2. The governing body, by ordinance, shall specify the procedure for determining whether a vacancy exists.
  3. If a vacancy is determined to exist, the governing body shall appoint an eligible person to the office who shall serve until his successor is elected at the next general municipal election and qualified. If the entire council is vacant, the district judge for the district in which the city or town is located shall appoint a person to fill each vacancy and serve until the next general municipal election at which time a successor shall be elected to fill the unexpired portion of each term.
  4. A vacancy in the office of mayor shall be filled only from the governing body.
  5. Vacancies in appointive offices shall be filled in the manner provided for initial appointments.

History. Laws 1965, ch. 112, § 7; W.S. 1957, § 15.1-7; Laws 1980, ch. 38, § 1; 1984, ch. 15, § 1; ch. 34, § 2; 1997, ch. 109, § 1; 2002 Sp. Sess., ch. 69, § 1.

Cross references. —

As to vacancy in office of mayor of first class city, see § 15-3-203.

§ 15-1-108. Powers and duties of mayor; appointment of mayor pro tem.

  1. Unless otherwise provided by statute, the mayor shall:
    1. Preside at all meetings of the governing body, and in his absence a councilman shall be appointed to act as mayor pro tem;
    2. Have superintending control of all officers and affairs of the city or town;
    3. Take care that the ordinances and laws are complied with;
    4. Administer oaths;
    5. Sign commissions and appointments and all bonds, contracts and other obligations required to be signed in the name of the city or town; and
    6. Have one (1) vote on all matters coming before the governing body upon which a vote is taken, except a vote:
      1. To override a veto;
      2. To confirm an appointment other than a vote to break a tie vote of the governing body; and
      3. Pursuant to a hearing for removal or discharge as provided in W.S. 15-2-102(b)(iv)(C) or 15-3-204(b)(iv)(C).
  2. Repealed by Laws 1984, ch. 15, § 2.

History. Laws 1965, ch. 112, § 8; W.S. 1957, § 15.1-8; Laws 1980, ch. 38, § 1; 1984, ch. 15, § 2; ch. 34, § 2; 1993, ch. 124, § 1; 2004, ch. 130, § 1.

The 2004 amendment, in (a)(vi)(C), substituted “W.S. 15-2-102(b)(iv)(C) or 15-3-204(b)(iv)(C)” for “W.S. 15-2-102(b)(iv)(B) or15-3-204(b)(iv)(B).”

Laws 2004, ch. 130, § 4, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 19, 2004.

Conflicting legislation. —

Laws 2004, ch. 130, § 3, provides: “Any other act adopted by the Wyoming legislature during the same session in which this act is adopted shall be given precedence and shall prevail over the amendments in this act to the extent that such acts are in conflict with this act.”

§ 15-1-109. When clerk may administer oaths.

  1. The clerk of any city or town may administer oaths to persons for any city or town purpose for which an oath is required or authorized by law.
  2. In adding his jurat to any oath he administers, the clerk shall attach the official seal of the city or town to the jurat.

History. Laws 1965, ch. 112, § 9; W.S. 1957, § 15.1-9; Laws 1980, ch. 38, § 1; 1985, ch. 209, § 1.

§ 15-1-110. Minutes of meetings and titles of ordinances passed to be published; exception; contents; publication of salary information of specified officials and employees.

  1. The governing body of any city or town shall designate a legal newspaper and publish once therein the minutes of all regular and special meetings of the governing body and the titles of all ordinances passed. If a newspaper is not published in the city or town the proceedings or ordinances shall be posted for at least ten (10) days in the city or town clerk’s office and in such other places as the governing body determines. The clerk of each city or town shall within twelve (12) days after adjournment of every meeting, furnish the newspaper a copy of the proceedings of the meeting. Except for salaries and wages published under subsection (b) of this section, the copy shall include any bill presented to the governing body stating the amount of the bill, the amount allowed, the purpose of the bill and the claimant. Claims for part-time employees may be summarized by department without listing each part-time employee. The newspaper shall publish the copy of proceedings within nine (9) days after receipt.
  2. A city or town required to publish minutes under subsection (a) of this section shall separately publish:
    1. Within sixty (60) days after the end of each fiscal year, the name, position, base annual salary of and amount of overtime pay paid to each full-time employee and each elected official. A brief statement shall accompany the salary publication specifying that all salaries are listed as base annual salaries or actual wages, not including any benefits such as health insurance costs, life insurance benefits and pension plans. The statement shall also indicate that any overtime the employee earned and was paid by the city or town is included;
    2. Repealed by Laws 2014, ch. 86, §  2.
  3. Repealed by Laws 2014, ch. 86, §  2.
  4. Subsection (b) of this section shall not apply to undercover personnel working in the law enforcement field.

History. Laws 1965, ch. 112, § 10; W.S. 1957, § 15.1-10; Laws 1973, ch. 212, § 1; 1980, ch. 38, § 1; 1983, ch. 54, § 1; 2014 ch. 86, §§ 1, 2, effective July 1, 2014; 2020 ch. 36, § 1, effective July 1, 2020.

The 2014 amendment, effective July 1, 2014, rewrote (b)(i); and repealed former (b)(ii) and (c) which read: “(ii) During March of each year, a complete list of all chief administrative officials, assistant administrative officials, elected officials, department heads and full-time employees of the city or town specified by name and position, excluding salaries.

“(c) As used in this section, ‘department head’ means any employee responsible for the operation of a major functional area of the city or town who reports directly to the chief administrative official.”

The 2020 amendment, effective July 1, 2020, in (b)(i) substituted “position, base annual salary of and amount of overtime pay paid to each” for “position and gross monthly salary of each,” “base annual salaries or actual wages” for “gross monthly salaries or actual monthly wages,” “benefits” for “fringe benefits,” “any overtime the employee earned and was paid” for “the salaries or wages do not include any overtime the employee may earn which would be paid,” and added “is included” at the end.

Intent of legislature in enacting this section was to insure that the business of each municipality in Wyoming would be subject to public scrutiny with respect to the expenditure of funds for all acquired debts. Record-Times, Inc. v. Wheatland, 650 P.2d 297, 1982 Wyo. LEXIS 381 (Wyo. 1982).

Section requires inclusion of listing of employees' salaries in minutes. —

The language of this section requires that cities and towns include a listing of employees' salaries in the minutes of council meetings which are submitted to the designated paper for publication. Record-Times, Inc. v. Wheatland, 650 P.2d 297, 1982 Wyo. LEXIS 381 (Wyo. 1982).

Applied in

Sheridan Newspapers, Inc. v. City of Sheridan, 660 P.2d 785, 1983 Wyo. LEXIS 289 (Wyo. 1983).

Law reviews. —

For case note, “Constitutional Law — A Constitutional Right of Access to State-Held Information. Sheridan Newspapers, Inc. v. City of Sheridan, 660 P.2d 785, 1983 Wyo. LEXIS 289 (Wyo. 1983),” see XIX Land & Water L. Rev. 719 (1984).

§ 15-1-111. Appropriations for advertisement of resources authorized; exception.

  1. The governing body of any city or town may make appropriations from the city or town general fund for:
    1. Advertising the resources of the city or town;
    2. Furthering its industrial development; or
    3. Encouraging exhibits at fairs, expositions and conventions.
  2. No appropriation may be for the express aid of any private citizen, firm or corporation.

History. Laws 1965, ch. 112, § 11; W.S. 1957, § 15.1-11; Laws 1979, ch. 85, § 1; 1980, ch. 38, § 1.

Cross references. —

As to advertising county resources, see § 18-3-521.

§ 15-1-112. Manner of disposing of municipal property; when advertising and bids not necessary.

  1. Except as otherwise provided in subsection (b) of this section and W.S. 15-1-113(a), before the sale of any property of any city or town valued at five hundred dollars ($500.00) or more, an advertisement of the intended sale, describing the property and the terms of the sale, shall be published at least once each week for three (3) consecutive weeks in a newspaper having general circulation in the community, announcing a public auction or calling for sealed bids for purchase of the property. The property shall be sold to the highest responsible bidder, unless the governing body of the city or town rejects all bids. The responsibility of the bidders shall be determined by the governing body of the city or town.
  2. Any city or town, upon terms the governing body thereof determines, without advertising the sale or calling for bids, and after a public hearing, notice of which shall include the appraised value of all real properties involved and notice of proposed terms of any contract with an independent agency pursuant to paragraph (iii) of this subsection and is published at least once each week for three (3) consecutive weeks in a newspaper of general circulation in the county in which the city or town is located, may:
    1. Sell any property to:
      1. The state of Wyoming for the use of any agency or instrumentality thereof;
      2. Any agency or instrumentality of the state or federal government authorized to hold property in its own name;
      3. Any political subdivision of the state;
      4. Any person acquiring the property for a use which the governing body determines will benefit the economic development of the municipality.
    2. Trade any real property the city or town owns for any other real property;
    3. Contract with an independent agent to sell individual parcels of land for development as reasonable cost housing alternatives for prospective homeowners, provided the parcels have not been previously developed beyond the installation of basic utilities and a foundation.

History. Laws 1965, ch. 112, § 12; W.S. 1957, § 15.1-12; Laws 1980, ch. 38, § 1; 1985, ch. 209, § 1; 1995, ch. 51, § 1; 1996, ch. 62, § 1; 1998, ch. 96, § 1.

Cross references. —

As to power of cities and towns to convey property, see § 15-1-103.

Council's discretion. —

In any sale of property made by the city, the council has the right to take into consideration its best economic, financial and industrial interests. Quackenbush v. Cheyenne, 52 Wyo. 146, 70 P.2d 577, 1937 Wyo. LEXIS 40 (Wyo. 1937).

Equity will not interfere with suit to restrain municipal officers in exercise of their discretionary power over control or disposition of municipal property, in the absence of illegality, fraud or clear abuse of authority. Quackenbush v. Cheyenne, 52 Wyo. 146, 70 P.2d 577, 1937 Wyo. LEXIS 40 (Wyo. 1937).

Taxpayers' suit not authorized. —

Mere fact that lots should have been sold for a somewhat higher figure and that sale was improvident does not, in absence of illegality, fraud or clear abuse of discretion authorize a suit on behalf of taxpayers, for the reason that sale of the property is by statute left to judgment of council. Quackenbush v. Cheyenne, 52 Wyo. 146, 70 P.2d 577, 1937 Wyo. LEXIS 40 (Wyo. 1937).

Exchange of land covered by section. —

Even if the power of a municipal corporation to buy and sell land includes the right to exchange land, the procedures outlined in this section would apply to the exchange. City of Buffalo v. Joslyn, 527 P.2d 1106, 1974 Wyo. LEXIS 245 (Wyo. 1974).

Avoiding appearance of unfairness. —

Even where the city officials are so well informed on the matter of a sale or exchange of land that no possible additional information could come to their attention by the advertisement of the intended disposition of city property, it is important to the officials of a city and the residents thereof that any appearance of unfairness be guarded against by complying with the provisions of this section. City of Buffalo v. Joslyn, 527 P.2d 1106, 1974 Wyo. LEXIS 245 (Wyo. 1974).

§ 15-1-113. Contracts for public improvements.

  1.
